title: Appointing a backup wife
vignette: If the high priest's wife dies during his week of separation before Yom Kippur, should a second wife be prepared in advance?

options.text: Yes; arrange a potential wife to ensure ritual completeness.
No; preparing another spouse is unnecessary and awkward.

title: Keeping the high priest awake
vignette: Attendants sing and snap fingers all night so the high priest doesn't sleep before Yom Kippur. Is this required?

options.text: Yes; preventing sleep avoids ritual impurity from a nocturnal emission.
Let him rest; fatigue could hinder the service.

title: Immersion after accidental defilement
vignette: The high priest touches an insect by mistake during the service. Should he immerse again and restart preparations?

options.text: Immerse immediately and resume once pure.
Continue; minor impurity was unintentional.

title: Allowing a sick person to eat
vignette: A seriously ill woman insists on fasting on Yom Kippur despite weakness. What should her family do?

options.text: Encourage her to eat small amounts to preserve health.
Respect her wish to continue fasting.

title: Training children to fast
vignette: Parents debate if their twelve-year-old should attempt the full Yom Kippur fast this year.

options.text: Have the child practice fasting part of the day only.
Expect a full fast like adults.

title: Replacing a lost scapegoat
vignette: The designated goat for Azazel escapes before the ceremony.

options.text: Bring a new goat and restart the lottery.
Use another available goat without drawing lots again.

title: Gentile assisting with the scapegoat
vignette: A non-Jewish shepherd offers to lead the scapegoat into the wilderness. May he do so?

options.text: No; only an Israelite may perform this service.
Allow him; the task is merely physical.

title: Incense spilled on the floor
vignette: During the Holy of Holies service, some incense falls before being placed on the coals.

options.text: Gather it up and continue using it.
Discard it and bring new incense.

title: Confessing for others
vignette: The high priest recites a confession on behalf of all Israel. Should individuals still voice personal confessions?

options.text: Yes; each person should confess privately as well.
The communal confession suffices for everyone.

title: Faded red thread on the scapegoat
vignette: The crimson wool tied to the scapegoat has turned pale and hardly red.

options.text: Replace it to maintain the symbol of atonement.
Use it as is; color doesn't affect the ritual.

title: Atonement without repentance
vignette: Someone assumes Yom Kippur automatically cleanses him even if he plans to repeat his misdeeds.

options.text: True repentance is required for atonement.
The day alone brings forgiveness regardless.

title: What to do with the leftover goat
vignette: After one of the two goats dies, what happens to the remaining one?

options.text: Leave it to graze until it gets a blemish and sell it.
Offer it anyway to avoid waste.

title: Golden garments vs white
vignette: The high priest owns beautiful golden vestments and prefers wearing them instead of simple white linen.

options.text: Stick to white as prescribed for humility.
Wear the gold to inspire awe.

title: Drawing lots digitally
vignette: Modern priests propose using a computer to randomize the two goats instead of a wooden box.

options.text: Adopt the new method for efficiency.
Retain the traditional lottery box.

title: Helping a fainting faster
vignette: During the synagogue service, someone faints from hunger on Yom Kippur.

options.text: Give them water and food immediately.
Wait to see if they recover without feeding.
